qas.question: What is a form of communication observed within plants?
What part of a plant communicates with rhizome bacteria, fungi, and insects within the soil?
How are the plant roots able to communicate with rhizome bacteria, fungi, and insects within the soil?
What is the meaning of the word neuron in Greek?
How do plants communicate to warn nearby plants of danger?
The plants leaves communicates with what in the soil?
This centralized system makes plant interactions possible?
The Hebrew word for 'neuron' is what?
During herbivory attack behavior what doesn't allow plants to communicate?
What can't plants overwrite when they are stressed?

context: Communication is observed within the plant organism, i.e. within plant cells and <a0_0>between plant cells<a0_0/>, between plants of the same or related species, and between plants and non-plant organisms, especially in the root zone. Plant <a1_0>roots<a1_0/> communicate with <b5_0>rhizome bacteria, fungi, and insects<b5_0/> within the soil. These interactions are governed by syntactic, pragmatic, and semantic rules,[citation needed] and are possible because of <a2_0>the decentralized "<b6_0>nervous<b6_0/> system" of plants<a2_0/>. The original meaning of the word "neuron" in Greek is "<a3_0><b7_0>vegetable fiber<b7_0/><a3_0/>" and recent research has shown that most of the microorganism plant communication processes are neuron-like. Plants also communicate <a4_0>via <b8_0>volatiles<b8_0/><a4_0/> when exposed to herbivory attack behavior, thus warning neighboring plants. In parallel they produce other volatiles to attract parasites which attack these herbivores. In stress situations plants can overwrite the <b9_0>genomes<b9_0/> they inherited from their parents and revert to that of their grand- or great-grandparents.[citation needed]
